msg: Transferred from the Adobe Open Source Subversion Repository
1. Extend the throw animation to perform overshoot and settle ("bounce") effects.
2. Allow a scrolled component to be "pulled" past its edges.
3. Match initial throw velocity to final scroll velocity.
4. Calculate throw duration with fixed deceleration factor.
Tests run: checkintests, manual, cyclone run by Joan
Transferred from the Adobe Open Source Subversion Repository

Add mouseWheelChanging event to VScrollBar, HScrollBar and Scroller.  The event is dispatched before the mouseWheel event modifies the scroll position.  The event can be canceled to prevent the mouseWheel handler's default behavior or the event's delta can be modified and that value will be used by the mouseWheel handler when calculating the new scroll position.  In RichEditableText, when pasting, add null check before accessing the TextScrap.  There is a bug in one or more version of the player such that this can be null at times.
QE notes: Hans said we will do a PARB review by email for the new event
Is noteworthy for integration: yes - new mouseWheelChanging event on VScrollBar, HScrollBar and Scroller
Transferred from the Adobe Open Source Subversion Repository
Added support for the liveDragging style to ScrollerBase in the same way it was added in SliderBase. In addition to the new style, this adds a protected pendingValue property to ScrollerBase.
Added a Scroller liveScrolling style that sets the liveDragging style on the Scroller's scrollbars.
QE notes: This is a new Scroller feature to be tested.
Transferred from the Adobe Open Source Subversion Repository
Fixing a scroller edge-case: If scroller's not on stage at time of mouseup (because someone clicked the back button), we don't RTE anymore, and we end the scroll immediately.
Transferred from the Adobe Open Source Subversion Repository
Fixing an issue where the scrollbars don't disappear after a throw when using itemRendererFunction.

This originally broke in SVN 17804 with the fix for SDK-27734. The reason is because instead of doing scroller.dispatchEvent(event) we now do mouseDownedDisplayObject.dispatchEvent(event) and have the event bubble. Unfortunately, with itemRendererFunction, sometimes mouseDownedDisplayObject is no longer on screen (just using itemRenderers don't have this issue because they stay on the display list and get re-used).

The absolute fix for this is to tell people if they must know when the END occurs, they should listen directly on the mouseDownedDisplayObject. Or, we could grab the display list at mouse down time, keep track of it, and manually dispatch events to every object in the display list hierarchy at mouse down time. Unfortunately, that seems a little heavy-handed.

So to fix this, we will dispatch a bubbling event to the mouseDownedDisplayObject, as we are doing today, and if that display object is not on the stage and is not a child of scroller, we will also dispatch the same bubbling event on the Scroller. It is not a perfect solution as the DataGroup inside could technically be listening for this event as well, but it seems like a good enough approximation to not worry about it for now. As mentioned before, if someone absolutely needs to know when the event is over, instead of relying on the bubbling event, they should attach a listener directly to the mouseDownedDisplayObject.
